metadata.product: TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses Square Nerd Eyeglasses Frame

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Hello Wren, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Jessica, and I'm a corporate representative from TIJN. We deeply value customer feedback, and we really appreciate you sharing your thoughts with us, especially through your recent review.

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Oh, you're welcome, Jessica. Happy to help. I mean, you know, if it helps improve things for others, then it's worth a few minutes.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Absolutely. Your review gave us some really insightful points, particularly the "Cute Design, Poor Execution" title. Could you perhaps elaborate a little on that initial impression? What was it about the design that initially caught your eye, and what was the first thing that made you think "execution"?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Hmm, yeah, well, I spend a lot of time on screens these days, even though I'm retired. My hobbies, you know, a bit of online gaming, catching up with family on video calls, just general browsing… it really adds up. My eyes were getting pretty dry and tired, and those tension headaches were becoming a regular thing. I’d heard about blue light glasses, and yours, the "square nerd" frames, they just looked… *cool*. Very modern, sleek, matte black. Visually, they ticked all the boxes for me. And the price! Very appealing, especially compared to some of the others I'd seen.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's great to hear about the aesthetic appeal and the value proposition. And just to clarify, Wren, you mentioned in your review something about a "student budget." Could you tell me a little more about that context?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Oh, that was a bit of an old line I had in my head, honestly. I've been retired for a few years now, so I'm not on a student budget myself anymore, thankfully. *chuckles* But I know a lot of people are, and I thought it was an important point for the product. For me, it was just a really nice bonus that they were so affordable, you know? Less of a commitment if they didn't work out. My screen time is probably on par with a college student though, so that part was accurate!

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: I understand completely. Thank you for clarifying that, Wren. So, the look and the price were definite draws. When you received them and took them out of that minimalist packaging – which you also noted – what was your very first physical impression? You mentioned they felt "incredibly light, almost too light."

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Right. They came in that little fabric pouch, which was nice, and a cleaning cloth. Very simple, nothing fancy, but effective. And they looked exactly like the pictures, which is always a relief with online shopping. But when I picked them up… yeah, they felt *flimsy*. Like, almost brittle. I expected them to have a bit more heft, you know, a more solid feel. And the hinges, they were a bit loose right out of the box. I remember thinking, "Are these going to last?" It just didn't inspire confidence for something I planned to wear every day.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: I see. So, the immediate tactile experience didn't quite match the visual appeal. That's really important feedback for our materials and manufacturing teams. You also noted the yellow tint upon putting them on. How significant was that for you in your daily activities?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Well, it was definitely there. Not like, *super* yellow, but enough to make whites look a bit creamy, or slightly off-white. And it did dull other colors a bit. For just reading articles online or, say, looking at documents in PDF format, it was manageable. I wouldn't say it was a deal-breaker for those tasks. But, you know, sometimes I dabble in a bit of amateur photo editing for my online gaming screenshots, or I'm looking at vibrant graphics for a new game. When I tried to do that with the glasses on, the color distortion was just too much. I had to take them off every single time. It became quite annoying.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's a very clear distinction between different use cases. It sounds like for general browsing or text, it was acceptable, but for anything requiring color accuracy, it was a significant impediment. Following on from that, you mentioned comfort was a "mixed bag." Can you elaborate on what specifically became uncomfortable during longer wear?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Yeah, at first, they were fine. So light, I almost forgot I had them on for the first hour or so. But if I was at my computer for, say, two or three hours continuously, that's when it started. The thin plastic arms, they just started to press in behind my ears. Nothing excruciating, but just this constant, low-level pressure that became irritating. And the nose pads, those molded plastic bits, they weren't sharp, but after a while, they'd leave a little red mark on the bridge of my nose and it felt mildly sore.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Hmm, so a pressure point issue, and the nose pads causing irritation after extended wear. Did the lightness of the frames contribute to any other comfort or wearability issues?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Oh, absolutely! They had this tendency to slide down my nose, especially if I leaned forward at all, like when I was really concentrating on something on my laptop screen. It meant I was constantly pushing them back up. Every few minutes, it felt like. And when you're trying to focus, that constant adjustment is just… disruptive. It breaks your concentration. So, between the pressure behind the ears, the nose irritation, and the sliding, they weren't really comfortable for long, focused periods.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That sounds incredibly frustrating, especially when you're trying to immerse yourself in something. Now, moving to the core function – the blue light blocking. You wore them diligently for two weeks. What were your expectations for the blue light blocking effect, and how did the actual experience compare?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: I really wanted these to be a game-changer. I was hoping for a dramatic reduction in eye strain, you know, feeling less tired by the end of the day. And definitely hoping for better sleep – falling asleep faster, waking up more rested. Those were my big hopes. What I actually got… *pauses* …the screens did feel a little softer, less harsh, I guess. That glare seemed somewhat reduced. But "dramatic reduction"? No. My eyes still felt tired. The headaches, they might have been *slightly* less frequent, but they definitely weren't gone. And sleep? Honestly, I didn't notice any real difference. It just felt like a very subtle comfort adjustment, not the therapeutic benefit I was after.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: So, the impact was much more subdued than what you had anticipated, almost imperceptible for the key issues you were trying to address. You also mentioned a persistent, minor internal reflection on the lenses. Could you describe that a bit more? Under what conditions did you notice it?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Oh, yeah, that was an odd one. It wasn't constant, but definitely noticeable. If I had a bright light source behind me, or even sometimes just the general ambient light in the room, I'd see a faint reflection of my own eye, or sometimes just a general hazy glare on the inside of the lens. It was like a little layer of visual "noise" that added to the overall distraction. Not terrible, but another one of those little things that accumulated to make the experience less than ideal.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Thank you, Wren, that's a very clear description. Given all these points – the build quality, the comfort issues, the color distortion, and the lack of significant blue light benefits – how do you now perceive the price and value? You initially found them super affordable.

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Well, for the price, I suppose you get what you pay for, right? They *were* cheap. And if you just want something that looks good and takes the *very* slightest edge off screen glare, maybe they're fine. But for me, wanting genuine relief from eye strain and headaches, and hoping for better sleep… they were a disappointment. So, from that perspective, even though they were affordable, the value wasn't there because they didn't deliver on their core promise for *my* needs. I mean, what's cheap if it doesn't work? It's just wasted money then, isn't it?

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's a very fair point, Wren. It sounds like the perceived value dropped significantly because the functional benefits didn't meet your expectations. Had you tried any other solutions for your eye strain or headaches before these glasses, or considered other brands? What would you look for in a "higher-quality option" now?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Before this, it was just… well, trying to take more breaks, looking away from the screen, that kind of thing. Which, honestly, wasn't enough. I hadn't tried any other blue light glasses. But now, if I were to invest in a higher-quality option, I'd definitely prioritize a few things. First, better build quality. Something that feels sturdy, not flimsy, with durable hinges. Second, actual, proven blue light blocking that delivers noticeable relief. I'd want more transparency on what percentage of blue light they block. Third, comfort for long wear. Padded nose pads, arms that don't dig in. And maybe, if possible, less color distortion or at least a way to mitigate it for specific tasks. I don't know if that's possible, but it would be ideal.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Those are excellent and very practical suggestions, Wren, and things we're definitely exploring. To put it directly, what specific improvements would you suggest we make to the TIJN "square nerd" glasses based on your experience?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Okay, let's see. Number one: materials. Use a stronger, more robust plastic for the frame. Number two: better hinges. They need to feel solid, not loose. Three: redesign the arms and nose pads for true long-term comfort – perhaps wider arms or silicone tips, and softer, adjustable nose pads. Four: significantly improve the blue light filtering without making the yellow tint unbearable, or maybe offer different tint levels. And five: address that internal reflection issue. It just makes the visual experience messy.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Those are very clear and actionable points, Wren. Thank you. Thinking about all this, if a friend or family member came to you and asked about these TIJN glasses, how likely would you be to recommend them, on a scale of 1 to 10, and why?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Hmm, on a scale of 1 to 10… I'd say a 3. Maybe a 4, at a push, for someone who just wants a stylish, affordable pair of glasses for *very* casual, short-term screen use and doesn't care much about the actual benefits. But for anyone looking for real relief from eye strain, headaches, or hoping for better sleep? No, I wouldn't recommend them. I'd tell them to save their money and invest in something better. The style is a 9 or 10, but the function… it just isn't there.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's very honest feedback, and we appreciate it. Finally, Wren, what would it take for you to consider switching to a competitor for your blue light blocking needs? What would that competitor have to offer that TIJN currently doesn't, based on your experience?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Basically, everything I just listed for improvements. A competitor would need to offer demonstrably better build quality, genuine, noticeable blue light blocking efficacy, superior comfort for extended wear, and minimal visual distortion or reflections. I'd be willing to pay more for that, absolutely. It's not about the lowest price for me anymore; it's about getting a product that actually delivers on its promises and helps me manage my screen time comfortably.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Wren, this has been incredibly helpful and detailed feedback. Your insights are invaluable as we look to improve our products. Just one last thing, considering your entire experience with the TIJN blue light blocking glasses, from purchase to your two weeks of diligent use, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being completely dissatisfied and 10 being absolutely delighted, what would your overall satisfaction rating be today?

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: Overall satisfaction? Probably a 3. As I said, they *look* good. But that's where the delight ends. The rest was a letdown.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Thank you, Wren. A 3. We really appreciate your candor and the time you've dedicated to this conversation. Your feedback will be directly shared with our product development and quality assurance teams. We genuinely want to make sure our products meet and exceed customer expectations, and your detailed account helps us immensely.

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: You're welcome, Jessica. I hope it helps. Thanks for listening.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Thank you again, Wren. Have a wonderful rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: Wren
transcript.text: You too. Bye now.
